name: Believe It Or Not Quiz | Mixed | 25 Questions

questions.text: In the U.S., about how many gallons of milk does the average cow give during a year?
questions.explanation:
1600.

	Most dairy cows are milked twice daily, in the early morning and afternoon.

questions.text: How many hummingbird eggs could fit into one ostrich egg?
questions.explanation:
5000.

	Ostrich eggs, the largest of all bird eggs, weigh 3.5 pounds and are 6 inches long.

questions.text: What did the son of England's George III once display a centerpiece of?
questions.explanation: live goldfish.

questions.text: Which of these does the huge French book called Larousse Gastronomique tell you how to cook?
questions.explanation:
camels.

	There are nine camel recipes in this cookbook.

questions.text: What was the East Room of the White House once used for?
questions.explanation:
laundry room.

	Abigail Adams hung her wash there to dry.

questions.text: What is the biggest object ever to disappear completely in quicksand?
questions.explanation:
a train.

	In Colorado in 1875.

questions.text: If you saved all the skin you shed in a year, what would it weigh as much of?
questions.explanation:
basketball.

	You shed up to 1 and a half pounds, or 24 ounces, of skin a {year;} a basketball weighs 20 to 22 ounces.

questions.text: What is the most common noncontagious disease in the world?
questions.explanation:
gum disease.

	Also called periodontal disease, it's the source of most dental problems in adults.

questions.text: Thomas Edison invented a machine for getting rid of what stubborn bug?
questions.explanation:
cockroaches.

	His machine electrocuted them.

questions.text: Which type of animals dined with the wealthy Earl of Bridgewater in 1820?
questions.explanation:
dogs.

	They wore napkins around their necks and usually behaved themselves.

questions.text: The Empire State Building once had a mooring on top. What was it for?
questions.explanation:
blimps.

	New York City's Empire State Building was the world's tallest building until 1954.

questions.text: Which of these never stops growing as long as it lives?
questions.explanation:
a palm tree.

	All trees keep growing although they differ in yearly growth depending on climate.

questions.text: If you could measure all the bacteria living in and on your body, what would it fill?
questions.explanation:
soup can.

	The ones not in your digestive tract would barely fill a thimble.

questions.text: How many times per minute does a canary's heart beat?
What was a sign of wealth in 19th century England?
questions.explanation:
an umbrella.

	Poorer people had to rent one or get wet.

questions.text: Where would you find your philtrum?
questions.explanation:
under your nose.

	The vertical crease between your nose and upper lip is called the philtrum.

questions.text: What was the first creature to travel in space?
questions.explanation:
fruit fly.

	The first mammal in space, however, was a rhesus monkey named Albert II in 1949. Laika, a dog, traveled aboard the Russian Sputnik II in 1957 and was the first animal to be put into orbit.

questions.text: In Utah in the 1870s what could a slot machine give you?
questions.explanation:
a divorce.

	A law firm in Corinne had the machine built. Divorce papers cost $2.50.

questions.text: A nest found in Ohio weighed more than a ton! What kind of bird builds a nest that big?
questions.explanation:
the bald eagle.

	Eagles add to their nest every year, so they get bigger and bigger.

questions.text: What do male butterflies like to lick?
questions.explanation:
stones.

	Scientists think they do this to take in sodium or other minerals.

questions.text: What did a Roman named Arpocras once eat?
questions.explanation: 4 tablecloths.

questions.text: Where does the male sea catfish carry its mate's eggs?
questions.explanation:
in his mouth.

	He goes without eating for eighty days until the eggs hatch.

questions.text: What color wedding dress is worn by most brides in China?
questions.explanation:
red.

	A color that represents happiness in the Chinese culture.

questions.text: Where was the tallest geyser eruption ever recorded?
questions.explanation:
New Zealand.

	The Waimango geyser reached 1500 feet in 1904.

questions.text: What did Mark Twain invent?
questions.explanation: elastic suspenders.
